title: Free-body diagram-sliding up and down incline

content.question: A wooden block is initially traveling upward along a rough inclined surface, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The block continues to travel up the incline a short distance, and then reverses direction and travels down the incline as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Which of the following pairs of free-body diagrams best represents the forces exerted on the block while it is traveling up the incline and traveling down the incline?

choices.label: Two figures are shown. Each figure shows a dot with an arrow extending from it. The first figure is labeled “Traveling Up the Incline.” The arrow is short and extends upward and to the left from the dot. The second figure is labeled “Traveling Down the Incline.” The arrow is short and extends downward and to the right from the dot.

Two figures are shown. Each figure shows a dot with three arrows extending from it. The first figure is labeled “Traveling Up the Incline.” The first arrow is short and extends upward and to the left from the dot. The second arrow is long and extends upward and to the right from the dot. The third arrow is long and extends downward and to the right from the dot. The second figure is labeled “Traveling Down the Incline.” The first arrow is short and extends downward and to the right from the dot. The second arrow is long and extends upward and to the right from the dot. The third arrow is long and extends downward and to the right from the dot.
